You said:
Can I remote to my computer from phone
ChatGPT said:

Yes, you can absolutely remote into your computer from your phone. There are several reliable apps and services that let you do this, depending on your setup (Windows, Mac, etc.). Here are a few good options:

1. Microsoft Remote Desktop

  • Best for: Windows PC

  • Requirements: Remote Desktop enabled on your PC (Windows Pro or Enterprise)

  • App: Available for iOS and Android

  • Setup:

    • Enable Remote Desktop on your PC

    • Make sure your PC is on and connected to the internet

    • Use the app to connect via your PCâ€™s IP or hostname

2. Chrome Remote Desktop

  • Best for: Cross-platform (Windows, Mac, Linux)

  • App: Available on both iOS and Android

  • Setup:

    • Install the Chrome Remote Desktop extension in your Chrome browser

    • Set up a PIN for secure access

    • Use the mobile app to connect

3. TeamViewer

  • Best for: Easy setup, support situations

  • App: Available on iOS and Android

  • Setup:

    • Install TeamViewer on both your computer and phone

    • Log in with the same account or use the access code

    • Can even wake up your PC if configured with Wake-on-LAN

4. AnyDesk

  • Best for: Lightweight alternative to TeamViewer

  • App: iOS/Android compatible

  • Setup: Similar to TeamViewer

5. Third-party apps for developers

  • If you're running bots or servers, you might want Termius (for SSH access), or VS Code Remote Server with GitHub Codespaces for code access/editing.

Let me know what system youâ€™re using and what you need access to (desktop UI, files, VS Code bots, etc.), and I can walk you through a tailored setup.

You said:
How bout if itâ€™s Linux really just want to se the bots. Have running in vs code
ChatGPT said:

Perfectâ€”since you're running Linux and mostly want to check on your bots in VS Code, you've got a few good lightweight and remote-friendly options. Hereâ€™s how to do it:

Option 1: VS Code + Remote SSH (Best Developer Experience)

If you have:

  • Your bots running on your Linux machine

  • VS Code installed on your desktop (server)

  • An SSH server running on the Linux box

You can use VS Code on your phone with an app like Blink Shell (iOS) or JuiceSSH (Android), or just use Termius on any device to SSH in and manage your bots.

But the real power comes from:

VS Code on another computer with Remote - SSH extension:

  1. Install the Remote - SSH extension in VS Code on your laptop.

  2. SSH into your Linux desktop.

  3. You can open the folder where your bots live and edit/debug them as if youâ€™re local.

To SSH from your phone (to just monitor):

  • Termius (iOS/Android):

    • Set up SSH access to your Linux machine.

    • Once connected, navigate to your bot folder.

    • Use htop, ps aux, or pm2 list (if using pm2) to see if theyâ€™re running.

    • You can also restart bots, edit files via command-line editors (like nano or vim), or pull updates from Git.

Option 2: Browser-Based VS Code (Code Server or VS Code Web)

You can self-host a web version of VS Code and access it from your phone browser.

Install Code Server:

  1. On your Linux box:

    bash
    curl -fsSL https://code-server.dev/install.sh | sh

  2. Start the server:

    bash
    code-server

  3. Access it via browser:

    • From your phone: https://<your-Linux-IP>:8080

    • Secure it with a password or domain + HTTPS

Now you can open VS Code right from your phoneâ€™s browser, check logs, restart bots, even write code.

Option 3: Tmux + SSH (Lightest & Quickest)

If youâ€™re just monitoring bots:

  • Use tmux or screen to keep bot sessions alive

  • SSH in from phone (via Termius or similar)

  • Reattach the session:

    bash
    tmux attach-session -t bots

Bonus Tip: If youâ€™re using pm2 to run your bots, itâ€™s super easy:

bash
pm2 list
pm2 restart bot-name
pm2 logs bot-name

Let me know how youâ€™ve got your bots running (pm2? forever? node directly?) and I can help you set up the best remote workflow.

You said:
I want to do the browser version letâ€™s do that
ChatGPT said:

Awesomeâ€”setting up the browser version of VS Code (via code-server) is a slick way to remotely check on and manage your bots from any device, including your phone. Letâ€™s walk through it step-by-step:

Step 1: Install code-server on your Linux machine

Run this in your terminal:

bash
curl -fsSL https://code-server.dev/install.sh | sh

This will download and install code-server globally.

Step 2: Start code-server

Once installed, start it with:

bash
code-server

On first run, it will output something like this:

arduino
  Web UI available at:
    http://127.0.0.1:8080/
    - Password: 123456abcdef

Important: Write down or copy the passwordâ€”itâ€™s needed to log in via the browser.

Step 3: Access it from your phone or another device

If you're on the same Wi-Fi network:

  1. Find your Linux machine's local IP:

    bash
    ip a | grep inet

    Look for something like 192.168.x.x

  2. On your phone, open a browser and go to:

    cpp
    http://192.168.x.x:8080

  3. Enter the password from earlier when prompted.

Step 4: (Optional) Make code-server run in the background

To keep it running even after logout or reboot:

bash
# Create systemd service
sudo systemctl enable --now code-server@$USER

Itâ€™ll now start on boot and run as a service in the background.

Optional: Secure with HTTPS + Custom Domain

If you want to access it from anywhere (outside your home):

  • Set up a dynamic DNS (like DuckDNS)

  • Port-forward 8080 from your router to your Linux box

  • Use a reverse proxy (like Nginx or Caddy) + Letâ€™s Encrypt for HTTPS

I can walk you through that if youâ€™re interested.

Let me know once it's running or if you hit a snagâ€”I can help troubleshoot.

ChatGPT said:

Nice catchâ€”you just need to install curl first. You can do that with:

bash
sudo apt update && sudo apt install curl -y

Once thatâ€™s done, rerun the install command for code-server:

bash
curl -fsSL https://code-server.dev/install.sh | sh

Let me know when thatâ€™s done or if you run into any errorsâ€”I got you.

ChatGPT said:

Nice! That means code-server is runningâ€”but itâ€™s only listening on 127.0.0.1, which means it wonâ€™t be accessible from your phone just yet. Letâ€™s fix that.

ðŸ› ï¸ Step 1: Edit the config file to listen on your local IP

Open the config file:

bash
nano ~/.config/code-server/config.yaml

Look for a line that says:

yaml
bind-addr: 127.0.0.1:8080

Change it to:

yaml
bind-addr: 0.0.0.0:8080

This tells it to listen on all network interfaces, so other devices on your network (like your phone) can connect.

ðŸ’¾ Step 2: Save and exit

In nano, press:

  • Ctrl + O â†’ save the file

  • Enter â†’ confirm the filename

  • Ctrl + X â†’ exit the editor

ðŸ” Step 3: Restart code-server

Stop it (if it's still running):

bash
Ctrl + C

Then restart it:

bash
code-server

Now you should see:

nginx
HTTP server listening on http://0.0.0.0:8080

ðŸ“± Step 4: Access it from your phone

  1. Get your Linux machineâ€™s local IP:

    bash
    ip a | grep inet

    Look for an IP like 192.168.x.x.

  2. On your phone, open your browser and go to:

    cpp
    http://192.168.x.x:8080

  3. Enter the password from the config file (or terminal output).

Let me know if you hit any roadblocks. Once this is up, youâ€™ll have VS Code in your pocket. ðŸ˜Ž

yaml

to:

yaml
bind-addr: 0.0.0.0:8080

So your full config.yaml will look like this:

yaml
bind-addr: 0.0.0.0:8080
auth: password
password: bbcb241c409a643d78603e0a
cert: false

âœ… After updating:

  1. Save the file (Ctrl + O, Enter, then Ctrl + X in nano).

bash
code-server

nginx

    nginx

how do i delete some of the lines
ChatGPT said:

Great question! If you're editing the config file using nano, hereâ€™s how to delete lines:

ðŸ“ To delete a line in nano:

  1. Navigate to the line you want to delete using the arrow keys.

  2. Press Ctrl + K
    This cuts (deletes) the entire line.

You can keep pressing Ctrl + K to delete more lines one by one if needed.

ðŸ”„ After editing:

  • Press Ctrl + O to save the file

  • Press Enter to confirm the filename

  • Press Ctrl + X to exit

Let me know if you want to trim anything specific from the config or if you're seeing extra lines you're not sure about.

You said:
Do i have to leave the terminal open running server
ChatGPT said:

Great questionâ€”by default, yes: if you just run code-server in the terminal, it will stop when you close the terminal or log out.

But you can fix that easily by setting it up to run in the background automatically. Here are two solid options depending on how hands-off you want to be:

âœ… Option 1: Run as a systemd service (recommended)

This makes code-server start in the background automatically at boot and stay running.

1. Enable the systemd service for your user:

bash
sudo systemctl enable --now code-server@$USER

This will start it immediately and make sure it starts every time the system boots.

2. To check its status later:

bash
systemctl status code-server@$USER

ðŸ•¶ï¸ Option 2: Keep it running in background with tmux or screen

This is a manual but flexible way if you donâ€™t want to set up a service yet.

1. Install tmux:

bash
sudo apt install tmux

2. Start a new session:

bash
tmux new -s code

3. Run code-server inside that session.

4. Detach from the session:

Press Ctrl + B, then D
Your server keeps running in the background.

5. To reattach:

bash
tmux attach -t code

Let me know which one you prefer and I can help you set it up if needed. Iâ€™d recommend Option 1 for long-term useâ€”itâ€™s clean and fire-and-forget.

ðŸ§ª To double-check itâ€™s running:

bash

ChatGPT said:

Thanks for that output! It looks like code-server tried to start as a systemd service but failedâ€”most likely because of a config issue or permissions problem. Letâ€™s troubleshoot it step-by-step.

ðŸ” Step 1: View the full error log

Run this command to get a more detailed explanation of why it failed:

bash
journalctl -u code-server@$USER --no-pager

That will show the full logs for the service and help pinpoint the issue (it might be something like an invalid config file, port conflict, or missing environment variable).

ðŸ› ï¸ Step 2: Check for common problems

Here are a few likely culprits we can knock out:

âœ… 1. Check if the config file is OK

Make sure your config file is valid YAML and looks like this:

yaml
bind-addr: 0.0.0.0:8080
auth: password
password: bbcb241c409a643d78603e0a
cert: false

Path to config file:

bash
~/.config/code-server/config.yaml

âœ… 2. Manually test the same command

Try running the actual systemd command manually and see if it errors out:

bash
/usr/bin/code-server

If that throws an error, itâ€™ll show up directly in your terminal, and weâ€™ll know exactly why the service failed.

Let me know what shows up when you run journalctl -u code-server@$USER --no-pager or /usr/bin/code-server and weâ€™ll knock it out fast.

Apr 01 23:41:18 christopher-ray-HP-ENVY-Desktop-795-00xx code-server[80306]: [2025-04-02T04:41:18.302Z] info code-server 4.98.2 e2c489dd00f163b1a8d959965b0c30c1a978a080 Apr 01 23:41:18 christopher-ray-HP-ENVY-Desktop-795-00xx code-server[80306]: [2025-04-02T04:41:18.303Z] info Using user-data-dir /home/christopher-ray/.local/share/code-server Apr 01 23:41:18 christopher-ray-HP-ENVY-Desktop-795-00xx code-server[80306]: [2025-04-02T04:41:18.306Z] error listen EADDRINUSE: address already in use 0.0.0.0:8080 Apr 01 23:41:18 christopher-ray-HP-ENVY-Desktop-795-00xx systemd[1]: code-server@christopher-ray.service: Main process exited, code=exited, status=1/FAILURE Apr 01 23:41:18 christopher-ray-HP-ENVY-Desktop-795-00xx systemd[1]: code-server@christopher-ray.service: Failed with result 'exit-code'. ChatGPT said:

Thanks for posting the logsâ€”they tell us exactly whatâ€™s going on:

âŒ EADDRINUSE: address already in use 0.0.0.0:8080

That means: something (probably your manually launched code-server) is already using port 8080, so the systemd service canâ€™t start because itâ€™s trying to bind to the same port.

âœ… Fix Options

ðŸ›  Option 1: Stop the running instance so the service can use the port

If you still have a manually launched code-server running, you can stop it:

bash
pkill -f code-server

Then try starting the service again:

bash
sudo systemctl start code-server@$USER

Check its status:

bash
systemctl status code-server@$USER

ðŸ”€ Option 2: Change the port used by the systemd service

If youâ€™d rather run both a manual and service version, you can give the service its own port.

Edit the config:

bash
nano ~/.config/code-server/config.yaml

Change:

yaml
bind-addr: 0.0.0.0:8080

to something like:

yaml
bind-addr: 0.0.0.0:8081

Save and exit, then restart the service:

bash
sudo systemctl start code-server@$USER

Then visit on your phone:

cpp
http://192.168.1.210:8081

Let me know which route you wanna take and Iâ€™ll guide you through it. Most folks go with Option 1 for simplicity.

You said:
What about when im away
ChatGPT said:

Great questionâ€”and yeah, you can absolutely access your code-server remotely, even when you're away from home. There are a few solid ways to do it, depending on how secure, easy, or fancy you want to get.

ðŸ›¡ï¸ Option 1: Use a secure tunnel (easiest + safest)

This is what I recommend to startâ€”itâ€™s super simple and safe.

âœ… Use Cloudflare Tunnel

Free, encrypted, and no port forwarding or firewall headaches.

ðŸ”§ Steps:

  1. Install cloudflared on your Linux machine:

    bash
    sudo apt install cloudflared

  2. Authenticate with Cloudflare (requires a free account + domainâ€”let me know if you want to skip this and use something else).

  3. Create a tunnel:

    bash
    cloudflared tunnel login
cloudflared tunnel create vscode
cloudflared tunnel route dns vscode.yourdomain.com vscode

  4. Then run:

    bash
    cloudflared tunnel run vscode

Once itâ€™s up, youâ€™ll be able to visit:

arduino
https://vscode.yourdomain.com

From anywhereâ€”even on your phoneâ€”with end-to-end encryption.

ðŸŒ Option 2: Port Forwarding on Your Router

This is the classic DIY method, but less secure unless you add encryption.

Youâ€™ll need to:

  • Login to your router

  • Forward port 8080 to your Linux machineâ€™s IP

  • Find your public IP (Google â€œwhatâ€™s my IP?â€)

  • Then access it via:

    cpp
    http://<your-public-ip>:8080

â— Warning:

  • Your code-server will be publicly exposed unless you add HTTPS and a strong password

  • I can walk you through setting up a reverse proxy + HTTPS with Letâ€™s Encrypt if you want to do it right

ðŸŒ Option 3: Use a Dynamic DNS + Reverse Proxy (DIY pro setup)

  • Get a free Dynamic DNS (like duckdns.org)

  • Use nginx or caddy to serve code-server behind HTTPS

  • Keep the domain secure + auto-renew SSL certs

This is the most customizable but takes a bit more effort.

ðŸ”’ My Pick for You:

Cloudflare Tunnel is ðŸ”¥ for devs like youâ€”secure, easy, and free.
You donâ€™t need a static IP, and no ports are exposed to the internet.

Let me know which route sounds best to you and Iâ€™ll guide you step-by-step. Want the Cloudflare route? DuckDNS? Or are you cool with port forwarding for now?

ðŸš€ Install cloudflared on Ubuntu

1. Download the latest .deb package from Cloudflare

bash
wget https://github.com/cloudflare/cloudflared/releases/latest/download/cloudflared-linux-amd64.deb

2. Install the package

bash
sudo dpkg -i cloudflared-linux-amd64.deb

3. (Optional) Clean up the installer

bash
rm cloudflared-linux-amd64.deb

âœ… Check it installed correctly:

bash
cloudflared --version

You should see something like:

yaml
cloudflared version 2024.x.x

Once itâ€™s installed, Iâ€™ll walk you through creating a secure tunnel to access code-server from anywhereâ€”let me know once you're ready!

Great questionâ€”you donâ€™t have to pay for a domain if you just want to test or use a temporary public link.

âœ… Option 1: Use trycloudflare.com (free, instant, no domain needed)

This is the fastest way to get a public link right now, and itâ€™s totally free.

Run this:

bash
cloudflared tunnel --url http://localhost:8080

That will:

  • Spin up a secure tunnel to your code-server

  • Give you a temporary public URL like:

    arduino
    https://glorious-wolf-123.trycloudflare.com

You can open that from your phone, laptop, or anywhere in the world!

ðŸ“ Notes:

  • That trycloudflare.com URL changes each time you run it

  • Itâ€™s perfect for testing, but not for long-term access

ðŸŒ Option 2: Want a permanent link?

If you want something like:

arduino
https://vscode.yourname.com

Youâ€™ll need:

  • A domain name (starts around $1â€“$12/year from places like Namecheap, Google Domains, or Cloudflare Registrar)

    • ðŸ”¹ DuckDNS

You said:
how secure will this be
ChatGPT said:

Excellent questionâ€”security should be a top priority, especially when you're exposing tools like VS Code to the internet.

The good news? Cloudflare Tunnel is extremely secure when set up properly. Here's a breakdown of what youâ€™re getting and how it stacks up:

ðŸ” Cloudflare Tunnel Security: Why It's Safe

âœ… No open ports

Unlike port forwarding, you donâ€™t expose any ports on your home network. Your server connects out to Cloudflareâ€”nothing can scan or attack your IP directly.

âœ… End-to-end encryption

Once you add your domain, Cloudflare will automatically issue a free SSL certificate for HTTPS. Your connection is encrypted from your browser to your Linux box.

âœ… Firewall-friendly

Because the connection is outbound (like your browser talking to a website), most firewalls donâ€™t block itâ€”and you donâ€™t have to tweak your router.

âœ… Built-in authentication

You can restrict access using:

  • A password (like you already have)

  • Or even Cloudflare Access (free) to require:

    • Login with Google/Microsoft

    • Email-based 2FA

    • IP whitelisting

ðŸš« What Youâ€™re Avoiding:

Insecure OptionRisk
Port forwardingExposes your home IP and server to the internet
No HTTPSAnyone can intercept traffic (especially on public Wi-Fi)
Weak passwordCan be brute-forced if not rate-limited

âœ… With Cloudflare Tunnel + Domain + Password:

You get:

  • âœ… Encrypted HTTPS connection

  • âœ… Hidden IP address

  • âœ… Password protection (or advanced auth)

  • âœ… Zero open ports

  • âœ… Scalable and reliable infra

Want maximum security?

We can even:

  • Set up Cloudflare Access so youâ€™re the only person who can log in

  • Disable password login entirely in code-server

  • Require login with your Gmail, fingerprint, or hardware key

Let me know your comfort levelâ€”basic password or full-blown login system? Either way, youâ€™re in really good hands with Cloudflare Tunnel.

You said:
ok got the domain on cloudflare RAYBOTS.ORG
ChatGPT said:

ðŸ”¥ Awesomeâ€”youâ€™re making moves, Christopher. raybots.org is a badass name for your setup!

Letâ€™s hook it up with Cloudflare Tunnel and route your secure code-server through it.

ðŸš€ Step-by-Step: Cloudflare Tunnel with Your Domain

âœ… Step 1: Connect your domain to Cloudflare (DNS setup)

If you haven't already:

  1. Go to https://dash.cloudflare.com

  2. Add raybots.org as a site

  3. Follow Cloudflareâ€™s instructions to update your domainâ€™s nameservers (at your registrar)

    • Usually takes 5â€“15 minutes to propagate

  4. Once you see "Active" next to your domain in Cloudflare, you're good to go

Let me know if thatâ€™s done or if you want help double-checking your DNS settings.

âœ… Step 2: Create and configure the tunnel

In your Linux terminal:

bash
cloudflared tunnel create vscode

This creates a named tunnel ("vscode") and outputs credentials.

âœ… Step 3: Create a config file for the tunnel

Create the folder (if it doesnâ€™t exist):

bash
mkdir -p ~/.cloudflared

Create the config file:

bash
nano ~/.cloudflared/config.yml

Paste this in:

yaml
tunnel: vscode
credentials-file: /home/christopher-ray/.cloudflared/<your-tunnel-id>.json

ingress:
  - hostname: code.raybots.org
    service: http://localhost:8080
  - service: http_status:404

âš ï¸ Replace <your-tunnel-id>.json with the filename that cloudflared output in Step 2
(You can also check it by listing the directory: ls ~/.cloudflared)

âœ… Step 4: Route the subdomain through Cloudflare

bash
cloudflared tunnel route dns vscode code.raybots.org

This tells Cloudflare to forward traffic from code.raybots.org to your tunnel.

âœ… Step 5: Start the tunnel

You can test it manually first:

bash
cloudflared tunnel run vscode

Once that works, weâ€™ll set it up as a service to start on boot.

ðŸ’» Access Your Code-Server Anywhere

Visit:

arduino
https://code.raybots.org

You'll see your familiar login screen, but nowâ€”accessible from anywhere, encrypted, and private.

You said:
ChatGPT said:

Perfectâ€”your domain raybots.org is active in Cloudflare. That means weâ€™re greenlit for the tunnel setup!

Next, letâ€™s hook everything up so you can access code-server from https://code.raybots.org.

âœ… Step-by-Step (Youâ€™re on Step 2 Now)

Step 2.1: Create the tunnel

Run this in your Linux terminal:

bash
cloudflared tunnel create vscode

It will output something like:

python
Created tunnel vscode with id 1a2b3c4d-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-yyyyyyyyyyyy

Write down or copy that tunnel IDâ€”you'll need it for the config file.

Step 2.2: Create the config file

bash
nano ~/.cloudflared/config.yml

Paste this (update the <your-tunnel-id>.json):

yaml
tunnel: vscode
credentials-file: /home/christopher-ray/.cloudflared/<your-tunnel-id>.json

ingress:
  - hostname: code.raybots.org
    service: http://localhost:8080
  - service: http_status:404

Replace <your-tunnel-id>.json with the actual filename (you can find it by running ls ~/.cloudflared after the tunnel is created).

Step 2.3: Route your subdomain

bash
cloudflared tunnel route dns vscode code.raybots.org

This connects the tunnel to your subdomain on Cloudflare.

Step 2.4: Start the tunnel manually (for now)

bash
cloudflared tunnel run vscode

If everything's good, you can now go to:

arduino
https://code.raybots.org

Log in with your usual code-server password.

Let me know once you're through this part (or drop your tunnel ID filename and Iâ€™ll fill in the config for you). After this, weâ€™ll make it start automatically at boot.

cloudflared tunnel create vscode 2025-04-02T05:02:34Z ERR Cannot determine default origin certificate path. You need to specify the origin certificate path by specifying the origincert option in the configuration file, or set TUNNEL_ORIGIN_CERT environment variable originCertPath= failed to create tunnel: couldn't create client to talk to Cloudflare Tunnel backend: Error locating origin cert: client didn't specify origincert path
ChatGPT said:

Ahh yepâ€”thatâ€™s a common bump when setting up Cloudflare Tunnels the first time. It just means your system hasn't been authenticated yet with Cloudflare.

ðŸ› ï¸ Fix: You need to run the login step first

This will generate the cert.pem file that Cloudflare uses to trust your system.

Run this:

bash
cloudflared tunnel login

This will:

  • Open a browser window

  • Ask you to log in to your Cloudflare account

  • Let you authorize access to your domain (raybots.org)

After it's done, Cloudflare will place an origin cert at:

bash
~/.cloudflared/cert.pem

Then you can go ahead and re-run:

bash
cloudflared tunnel create vscode

Let me know once youâ€™ve done the loginâ€”it only needs to happen once per machine. After that, youâ€™ll be golden.

You said:

ChatGPT said:

Perfectâ€”youâ€™re getting close! That message just means you're trying to run the file as if it were a command. But cert.pem is just a file, not something you execute.

âœ… Letâ€™s verify it exists (and move on):

Run this to just list the file:

bash
ls -l ~/.cloudflared/cert.pem

You should see output like:

swift
-rw------- 1 christopher-ray christopher-ray 2048 Apr 2 00:10 /home/christopher-ray/.cloudflared/cert.pem

If that shows upâ€”awesome, you're authenticated, and we can proceed.

ðŸ§± Next step: Create the tunnel again

bash
cloudflared tunnel create vscode

    service: http://localhost:8080

You said:
Thats awesome, so same question do i need to keep this open, how can i make sure it is always running even if i close this window
ChatGPT said:

Yesss I love that itâ€™s working! ðŸ”¥ You're now running secure, remote VS Code on your own domain. Thatâ€™s huge.

ðŸ› ï¸ Now: Make the Tunnel Run Automatically (Even After Reboots)

Since you're asking the same thing as earlierâ€”"do I need to keep this terminal open?"â€”right now, yes. But we can make Cloudflare Tunnel run in the background at boot, just like we did with code-server.

âœ… Step 1: Create a systemd service for the tunnel

Run:

bash
sudo nano /etc/systemd/system/cloudflared-vscode.service

Paste this in:

ini
[Unit]
Description=Cloudflare Tunnel for code-server (vscode)
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=simple
User=christopher-ray
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/cloudflared tunnel --config /home/christopher-ray/.cloudflared/config.yml run
Restart=always
RestartSec=3

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

ðŸ” Make sure the User is christopher-ray, and that cloudflared is in /usr/local/bin (run which cloudflared to confirmâ€”adjust path if needed).

âœ… Step 2: Enable and start the service

âœ… Step 3: Check status

You said:
raybots.orgâ€™s DNS address could not be found. Diagnosing the problem.
ChatGPT said:

Got itâ€”if youâ€™re seeing â€œDNS address could not be foundâ€, that usually means one of two things:

ðŸš¨ Likely Causes:

1. The DNS record wasn't created properly

When you ran:

bash
cloudflared tunnel route dns vscode code.raybots.org

it should have added a CNAME record in your Cloudflare dashboard for code.raybots.org.

ðŸ‘‰ Letâ€™s confirm it:

âœ… Check Your Cloudflare DNS Settings

  1. Go to dash.cloudflare.com

  2. Click your domain: raybots.org

  3. Go to the DNS tab

  4. Look for a record like:

    yaml
    TYPE: CNAME
NAME: code
TARGET: your-tunnel-id.cfargotunnel.com
PROXY STATUS: Proxied (orange cloud)

If itâ€™s missing, re-run:

bash
cloudflared tunnel route dns vscode code.raybots.org

2. DNS needs time to propagate

If you just added the DNS record (or changed nameservers), it might take a few minutes to fully update.

ðŸ§ª Quick test:

Run this to see if your DNS is visible publicly:

bash
nslookup code.raybots.org

If it says "NXDOMAIN" or â€œcan't find,â€ then DNS isn't live yet.

âœ… Next Steps:

Letâ€™s do this:

  1. Check the DNS tab in Cloudflare

  2. Make sure the CNAME record for code.raybots.org is there

  3. If itâ€™s missing, re-run the tunnel route command

  4. Wait ~5â€“10 minutes and retry

Let me know what you see in the DNS settingsâ€”or drop a screenshot if easier. Weâ€™ll get it fixed fast.

Recommended steps to complete zone set-up Hide Add an A, AAAA, or CNAME record for www so that www.raybots.org will resolve. Add an A, AAAA, or CNAME record for your root domain so that raybots.org will resolve. Add an MX record for your root domain so that mail can reach @raybots.org addresses or set up restrictive SPF, DKIM, and DMARC records to prevent email spoofing. You said:
node
ChatGPT said:

Perfectâ€”if your bots are running as regular Node.js scripts, we can check them directly, and I highly recommend putting them under PM2 management next.

ðŸ‘€ Step 1: Check for running Node bots

Run this in your terminal (inside VS Code or via SSH):

bash
ps aux | grep node

You should see something like:

yaml
christopher-ray  1234  0.5  node mybot.js
christopher-ray  5678  0.4  node meme-sniper.js

That tells you:

  • Which bots are running

  • Their process IDs (PIDs)

  • How much CPU/memory theyâ€™re using

ðŸ§  Step 2: (Recommended) Install PM2 for easier management

PM2 lets you:

  • Start bots and keep them alive forever

  • Auto-restart them if they crash

  • View logs

  • Monitor usage

  • Start everything on boot

Install PM2 globally:

bash
npm install -g pm2

Then start a bot like this:

bash
pm2 start mybot.js --name raybot

And check all bots:

bash
pm2 list

To make PM2 auto-start your bots after a reboot:

bash
pm2 startup
pm2 save

Let me know:

  • What your main bot files are called

  • If you want help converting them over to PM2

  • Or if you'd like to add a lightweight web dashboard to see their status in real time

Youâ€™re almost running a full remote command center ðŸš€

You said:
So if i run a bot from the browser will it show up on computer at home
ChatGPT said:

Yepâ€”exactly! ðŸŽ¯

When you run a bot from your browser (via code-server), you're actually running it on your home computerâ€”just controlling it remotely through the browser.

ðŸ§  How It Works

  • You access VS Code in the browser from anywhere (https://code.raybots.org)

  • You open a terminal in code-server (or run your script)

  • The code runs on your Linux machine at home, not on your phone or laptop

So yeahâ€”if you run:

bash
node mybot.js

from your phone or laptop, it executes at home, and you'll be able to see it if you check from:

  • A physical terminal on that computer

  • A second browser session

  • Or even SSH

ðŸ” To Confirm Itâ€™s Running

You can verify from anywhere with:

bash
ps aux | grep node

Or watch the logs/output right there in the terminal you launched it from.

ðŸ” Example Use Case:

  • You're out having coffee â˜•

  • You pull out your phone, go to code.raybots.org

  • Open a terminal, type node sniperbot.js

You said:
yes it is running on the browser correctly but i dont see a physical terminal running on the machine. so if i close the browser does the bot stop
ChatGPT said:

Ahh great observationâ€”and youâ€™re absolutely right to ask that. Hereâ€™s the real talk:

ðŸ” If you start a bot from the browser and close the browser tab, what happens?

ðŸ’» What actually happens:

  • You're running the bot in a remote shell inside code-server, not a standalone background process.

  • So if you close the terminal tab inside VS Code, or if code-server crashes or restarts, your bot process will also stop.

âŒ Itâ€™s not running in a persistent session (like tmux or PM2), so:

  • It does not show in a terminal on your local physical machine

  • It will stop if you:

    • Close the browser tab

    • Reload code-server

    • Reboot the machine

    • Disconnect the network

âœ… How to Keep Bots Running After Closing the Browser

If you want the bot to keep running even if you close your browser, here are two easy options:

ðŸ§± Option 1: Run it in tmux (manual but easy)

  1. Install tmux (if you havenâ€™t):

    bash
    sudo apt install tmux

  2. Start a new session:

    bash
    tmux new -s bots

  3. Inside that session, run your bot:

    bash
    node mybot.js

  4. Detach from the session (bot keeps running):

    css
    Ctrl + B, then D

  5. Reconnect later with:

    bash
    tmux attach -t bots

ðŸ§  Option 2: Use pm2 (runs forever, even after reboot)

  1. Install pm2:

    bash
    npm install -g pm2

  2. Start your bot:

    bash
    pm2 start mybot.js --name raybot

  3. Save the state so it starts after reboot:

    bash
    pm2 save
pm2 startup

TL;DR:

ActionDoes the bot keep running?
Close browser tabâŒ No
Close code-server sessionâŒ No
Use tmuxâœ… Yes
Use pm2âœ… Yes (even across reboots)

Let me know if you want me to set up a one-click command inside VS Code that starts your bots in tmux or pm2 automatically. Super clean setup ðŸ’¯

ChatGPT said:

Ooo good catch, and thatâ€™s really important to check. ðŸ‘€

If you accessed https://code.raybots.org and it didnâ€™t ask for your password, then one of two things is happening:

ðŸ§  Possibility 1: Youâ€™re already logged in (session cached)

  • code-server stores a session cookie after you log in once

  • So if youâ€™re on the same browser/device, itâ€™ll just keep you logged in

  • âœ… This is normal behavior, and you can clear it by:

    • Logging out from the gear icon in the lower left of code-server

    • Or clearing cookies for the domain

ðŸš¨ Possibility 2: Authentication is disabled (not good)

Letâ€™s make sure your code-server config still has auth: password enabled.

Run this to check:

bash
cat ~/.config/code-server/config.yaml

You should see:

yaml
auth: password
password: bbcb241c409a643d78603e0a

If auth: none is there insteadâ€”we need to fix that ASAP.

ðŸ” Want to test it?

arduino

ðŸ§  Tip: How long does it stay logged in?

By default, code-server keeps your session alive until:

  • You log out manually (lower left corner gear > â€œLog Outâ€)

  • You clear cookies for the site

  • You restart code-server

So no worriesâ€”youâ€™re still protected.

You said:
ya private window asked for password, got scared because my phone said unsecure
ChatGPT said:

Ah yeah, totally understandableâ€”and honestly, your phone giving you the â€œunsecureâ€ warning is legit. You're seeing that because:

ðŸ” code.raybots.org is using HTTPS, butâ€¦

â— It's not using a valid SSL certificate from a trusted authority (like Let's Encrypt via Cloudflare)

Right now, the connection looks something like this:

  • Your phone hits https://code.raybots.org

  • Cloudflare tunnels to your home server over plain http://localhost:8080

  • So the browser says: â€œWhoa, this might not be fully secureâ€

âœ… But Hereâ€™s the Good News:

This is still encrypted end-to-end by Cloudflare Tunnelâ€”meaning:

  • Your real IP is hidden

  • Traffic is encrypted

  • Youâ€™re safe from eavesdropping

Itâ€™s just your browser saying:

"I can't fully verify this certificateâ€”so proceed with caution"

ðŸ” Want to Fix That Warning?

You can make it fully secure (green lock âœ…) by doing one of these:

Option 1: Use Cloudflareâ€™s free SSL + Zero Trust Access (recommended)

  • Cloudflare handles the cert

  • We leave your local code-server at http://localhost:8080

  • You get HTTPS + login protection + full trust âœ…

Weâ€™re almost already thereâ€”you just need to:

  1. Enable Full (strict) SSL in Cloudflare

  2. Optionally set up Cloudflare Access to require login via Google/email/etc.

Option 2: Add HTTPS support on your local code-server

  • Generate a cert using Letâ€™s Encrypt or a self-signed cert

  • Point code-server to use it

  • Can get a little trickier but doable if you prefer internal TLS

Want me to help you finish the lock icon upgrade? ðŸ”’

We can have it 100% green-secure in about 10 more minutes, and youâ€™ll have the safest DIY dev setup around. Let me know if you want that.

You said:
is it nesacary
ChatGPT said:

Solid questionâ€”and the honest answer is:

ðŸ” No, itâ€™s not strictly necessary for your setup right now.

You're already protected by:

âœ… Cloudflare Tunnel â€” encrypts your traffic from the internet to your home
âœ… Password authentication â€” so no one can just access your code-server
âœ… No open ports â€” your home IP is completely hidden from the world

So why the browser warning?

Because your browser doesnâ€™t see a traditional SSL certificate on your local serverâ€”so it freaks out a little, even though Cloudflare is handling the security.

Think of it like:

"Hey, this door is locked and secureâ€¦ but the key isn't in the format I recognize."

ðŸ” Should you add full HTTPS?

Not required if it's just you and:

  • You're not hosting anything public

  • Youâ€™re okay with the warning in private/incognito mode

  • You trust the device you're using

Then youâ€™re totally fine. Likeâ€¦ really. Your tunnel is already encrypted.

âœ… You should do it later if:

  • You want a green lock and no browser warnings

  • Youâ€™re building a public dashboard or tool

  • You want that final polish to feel â€œproduction-gradeâ€

TL;DR:

You're safe as-is.
Browser warning = cosmetic.
Cloudflare = still encrypted.
Lock icon = optional.

You said:
ok one more thing in my bot folder is my .env file if i wher to walk away from a computer with my browser open someone could click on the .env file and see my private keys, is there a way to maek them hidded
ChatGPT said:

Ahhh yesâ€”youâ€™re absolutely right to think about this. That .env file is sacred territory when it comes to API keys, wallet private keys, secrets, etc. ðŸ”

And yepâ€”if your browser is left open and unlocked, someone could totally click and view it. But don't worry, there are a few smart ways to protect it, depending on how tight you want the security.

ðŸ” Option 1: Donâ€™t leave your browser open ðŸ˜…

Obvious but important. If you walk away:

  • Log out of code-server (bottom left gear â†’ Log Out)

  • Or at least lock your computer

That said, letâ€™s talk about actual file-based protections:

ðŸ›¡ï¸ Option 2: Restrict access to the .env file

In your terminal, run:

bash
chmod 600 .env

That makes the file:

  • Readable only by you (the user who owns it)

  • Not even viewable by other users on the system

In VS Code, it might still show up in the file explorerâ€”but someone wonâ€™t be able to open it unless they're logged in as your user.

ðŸ‘ï¸ Option 3: Hide it in the sidebar in VS Code

You can tell code-server not to show .env in the file explorer sidebar.

  1. In your code-server workspace, go to:

    • File â†’ Preferences â†’ Settings (or press Ctrl+,)

  2. Search for:

    pgsql
    files.exclude

  3. Add this:

    json
    {
  "**/.env": true
}

Now itâ€™ll still exist and be readable by your botâ€”but wonâ€™t appear in the UI to casually click on.

ðŸ§  Option 4: Use environment variables instead of a .env file

If youâ€™re up for it eventually, you could:

  • Delete the .env file

  • Set variables directly in your .bashrc, .profile, or use pm2's environment system

But thatâ€™s for later if you want to go pro-dev.

âœ… What Iâ€™d Recommend Right Now

Do these two:

  1. Run:

    bash
    chmod 600 ~/.env

  2. Add .env to files.exclude in VS Code settings so it doesnâ€™t show

And if youâ€™re walking away, just log out or close the browser tab. Thatâ€™ll give you good peace of mind without overcomplicating things.

Let me know if you want me to help lock down any other secretsâ€”or rotate your keys if you think theyâ€™ve been exposed. Youâ€™re thinking like a pro now ðŸ”ðŸ§ 

You said:
hmm i still see them after the exclude
ChatGPT said:

Good eyeâ€”and yep, that's because the files.exclude setting in VS Code (and code-server) only hides files in the file explorer sidebar. It doesnâ€™t stop you from manually opening them, and sometimes it doesnâ€™t apply until a reload.

Let's make sure itâ€™s done correctly and cover a stronger backup method too ðŸ‘‡

âœ… Double-check your exclude setting

You want to set this in your settings.json file directly.

1. Open your command palette:

css
F1 or Ctrl+Shift+P

Search for:

pgsql
Preferences: Open Settings (JSON)

Then add this inside the JSON block:

json
"files.exclude": {
  "**/.env": true
},
"search.exclude": {
  "**/.env": true
}

This:

  • Hides it from the file explorer

  • Prevents it from showing up in global searches

ðŸ”„ You may need to reload the code-server tab after saving that setting to apply it.

ðŸ§± If you want to really protect it (stronger than hide):

Hereâ€™s an extra layer:

2. Move your .env to a private folder and symlink it

Letâ€™s say you move it to a safer spot like:

bash
mkdir ~/.secrets
mv ./my-bot/.env ~/.secrets/mybot.env

Then create a symbolic link (so your bot can still use it):

bash
ln -s ~/.secrets/mybot.env ./my-bot/.env

Now it's not in the bot folder, not visible in the browser, but still usable by your code.

ðŸ” And donâ€™t forget:

bash
chmod 600 ~/.secrets/mybot.env

So even if someone tried poking around as a different user or in VS Code, they couldnâ€™t open it without your user permission.

Let me know which method you like bestâ€”UI hide, hard restrict, or stealth symlinkâ€”and Iâ€™ll walk you through anything. You're thinking like a security-minded dev now. ðŸ”ðŸ’¡

You said:
Preferences: Open Settings (JSON) bash: syntax error near unexpected token ('
ChatGPT said:

Ah gotcha! That command â€” Preferences: Open Settings (JSON) â€” is not meant to be typed into the Linux terminal.

Itâ€™s something you trigger inside code-serverâ€™s interface, like a keyboard shortcut in the VS Code UI.

âœ… Here's how to do it properly:

ðŸ‘‰ Inside your browser, in code-server:

  1. Press **F1** or **Ctrl + Shift + P**
    (This opens the Command Palette)

  2. Type:

    pgsql
    Preferences: Open Settings (JSON)

  3. Select it from the dropdown

  4. It will open a settings.json file

  5. Add this block (or merge with whatâ€™s already there):

json
"files.exclude": {
  "**/.env": true
},
"search.exclude": {
  "**/.env": true
}

  1. Save the file (Ctrl + S)

  2. Reload the browser tab to make sure the file explorer updates

That will hide .env from the file tree and search, but still let your bot scripts use it.

Let me know once you've got it open or if you want help cleaning up the settings format. You're doing all the right things here ðŸ”ðŸ’»

You said:
does it matter where i put it
ChatGPT said:

Great questionâ€”and yes, it does matter where you put it in the settings.json file.

ðŸ§  Hereâ€™s how it should look:

Your settings.json is just a big JSON object ({}), so all entries must be inside the outer curly braces and separated by commas.

âœ… Example of correct structure:

json
{
  "files.exclude": {
    "**/.env": true
  },
  "search.exclude": {
    "**/.env": true
  },
  "editor.tabSize": 2,
  "workbench.startupEditor": "none"
}

If you already have settings in there, just add the "files.exclude" and "search.exclude" lines as new entries, separated by commas from the others.

âŒ Common mistakes to avoid:

  • Putting the block outside the {} braces

  • Forgetting a comma between entries

  • Duplicating keys like "files.exclude" (combine them instead)

Let me know what you already have in your settings.json if youâ€™re unsureâ€”Iâ€™ll help you fit it in cleanly without breaking anything. Want to paste it here?

You said:
can i just add it at the bottom
ChatGPT said:

Yes! âœ… You can absolutely add it at the bottom, as long as you:

  • Put it inside the curly braces {}

  • Add a comma before it if thereâ€™s a setting directly above it

ðŸ”§ Example:

If your current settings.json looks like this:

json
{
  "editor.tabSize": 2
}

Youâ€™d update it to:

json
{
  "editor.tabSize": 2,
  "files.exclude": {
    "**/.env": true
  },
  "search.exclude": {
    "**/.env": true
  }
}

ðŸ’¡ Make sure not to put it after the closing } or forget a comma if thereâ€™s another setting above.

Once saved, reload your browser tab and .env should vanish from the sidebar and searches. Let me know if it works or if you want me to double-check anything. You're nearly bulletproof now ðŸ”ðŸ›¡ï¸

You said:
well this is a huge file so let me show you

Just drop it inâ€”Iâ€™ll handle the merge and send it back ready to copy-paste. ðŸ”§ðŸ’¯

You said:
// Controls whether 'Peek References' or 'Find References' is invoked when selecting CodeLens references. // - peek: Show references in peek editor. // - view: Show references in separate view. "references.preferredLocation": "peek", // Enable/disable the floating indicator that shows when focused in the simple browser. "simpleBrowser.focusLockIndicator.enabled": true, }
ChatGPT said:

Thanks! ðŸ™Œ You're right at the bottom of the fileâ€”and I see the closing } at the end. Youâ€™re super close!

Hereâ€™s the updated version with your new settings added correctly before the final closing brace, and with the necessary comma after the last existing setting:

âœ… Use this:

json
// Controls whether 'Peek References' or 'Find References' is invoked when selecting CodeLens references.
//  - peek: Show references in peek editor.
//  - view: Show references in separate view.
"references.preferredLocation": "peek",

// Enable/disable the floating indicator that shows when focused in the simple browser.
"simpleBrowser.focusLockIndicator.enabled": true,

"files.exclude": {
  "**/.env": true
},
"search.exclude": {
  "**/.env": true
}
}

ðŸ”§ Note:

  • I removed the trailing comma after "simpleBrowser.focusLockIndicator.enabled": true, â€” that was outside the object, which would cause a JSON error.

  • If your file already has other settings at the top, make sure everything is inside the outer { ... }.

âœ… After saving:

  • Reload your browser tab

  • .env should disappear from the sidebar and search

  • Your bot still works because it can still read the file from disk

Let me know how it goesâ€”or feel free to upload the full file if you're unsure!

You said:
so i would like to share how to set this up with others without giving any of my sensitive info that is in this thread is it possible for you to format a set of instructions to do so
ChatGPT said:

Absolutely, Christopherâ€”thatâ€™s an awesome idea. ðŸ™Œ Iâ€™ll create a clean, step-by-step guide for how others can set up exactly what you did, but without any of your personal or sensitive info (no domains, passwords, keys, etc.).

ðŸ“˜ Secure Remote Code-Server with Cloudflare Tunnel: A Step-by-Step Guide

âš™ï¸ Requirements

  • A Linux machine (can be at home or cloud-based)

  • A free Cloudflare account

  • A registered domain (you can use Cloudflare Registrar or any other provider)

  • Node.js installed (for bot developers)

ðŸ” Step 1: Install code-server

bash
curl -fsSL https://code-server.dev/install.sh | sh

Start it once to generate the config:

bash
code-server

Then exit it (Ctrl+C).

ðŸ“ Step 2: Configure code-server

Edit the config:

bash
nano ~/.config/code-server/config.yaml

Update it like so:

yaml
bind-addr: 0.0.0.0:8080
auth: password
password: your-secure-password-here
cert: false

Save and exit.

ðŸš€ Step 3: Set up code-server to run as a service

bash
sudo systemctl enable --now code-server@$USER

Check status:

bash
systemctl status code-server@$USER

ðŸŒ Step 4: Install cloudflared

bash
wget https://github.com/cloudflare/cloudflared/releases/latest/download/cloudflared-linux-amd64.deb
sudo dpkg -i cloudflared-linux-amd64.deb

ðŸ” Step 5: Authenticate with Cloudflare

bash
cloudflared tunnel login

This opens a browser to connect your Cloudflare account and authorize your domain.

ðŸ”§ Step 6: Create a named tunnel

bash
cloudflared tunnel create vscode

Copy the generated .json credential filename (youâ€™ll need it in the next step).

ðŸ“ Step 7: Create your tunnel config

bash
mkdir -p ~/.cloudflared
nano ~/.cloudflared/config.yml

Paste this (replacing the filename and subdomain):

yaml
tunnel: vscode
credentials-file: /home/your-username/.cloudflared/your-tunnel-id.json

ingress:
  - hostname: code.yourdomain.com
    service: http://localhost:8080
  - service: http_status:404

ðŸŒ Step 8: Route the subdomain

bash
cloudflared tunnel route dns vscode code.yourdomain.com

ðŸŸ¢ Step 9: Run the tunnel (or set it as a service)

To run manually:

bash
cloudflared tunnel run vscode

To run it automatically:

bash
sudo nano /etc/systemd/system/cloudflared-vscode.service

Paste:

ini
[Unit]
Description=Cloudflare Tunnel for code-server (vscode)
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=simple
User=your-username
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/cloudflared tunnel --config /home/your-username/.cloudflared/config.yml run
Restart=always
RestartSec=3

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

Then enable and start it:

bash
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl enable --now cloudflared-vscode

ðŸ” Optional: Hide your .env or secrets in VS Code

Edit VS Code settings (F1 â†’ Preferences: Open Settings (JSON)):

json
"files.exclude": {
  "**/.env": true
},
"search.exclude": {
  "**/.env": true
}

Or move .env to a secure directory and symlink it.

âœ… Done!

Visit https://code.yourdomain.com, log in with your password, and you're good to go!

Let me know if you want a sharable PDF/Markdown version of this, or a version tailored for your own future blog or GitHub repo!

ChatGPT said:

Absolutelyâ€”itâ€™s totally possible to set up code-server with a Cloudflare Tunnel on Windows, and Iâ€™d love to help you build a walkthrough for that too. ðŸ‘‡

âœ… Hereâ€™s what weâ€™ll cover in the Windows version:

ðŸ”§ Tools you'll need:

  • Windows 10/11

  • PowerShell (comes built-in)

  • Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) or Git Bash for Linux-like tools

  • code-server installed

  • cloudflared installed

  • A domain connected to Cloudflare

ðŸš€ Want to go WSL route or native Windows?

Youâ€™ve got two ways to do it:

Option 1: WSL (Recommended)

  • You install Ubuntu (or another distro) via WSL

  • Run everything as if you're on Linux

  • Exact same steps as the Linux guide (but we tweak tunnel service setup)

Option 2: Native Windows + PowerShell

  • Install code-server via Node.js

  • Run cloudflared as a scheduled task or background process

  • Configure .yaml files using Notepad++

ðŸ§  Suggested: Use WSL

It gives you a Linux environment on Windows, so your current setup guide will work almost exactly the same. You just run the Cloudflare Tunnel and code-server in the WSL shell.

  1. WSL is already installed, or

  2. Should we include how to install WSL and Ubuntu too?

You said:
lets make it easy and act as if they dont want to fool with linux at all, really just make whay i have but a windows version that is just as secure
ChatGPT said:

Boom, I got you. ðŸ’¥ Letâ€™s make a straightforward Windows-native setup for running code-server behind a secure Cloudflare Tunnel, without needing Linux, WSL, or any extra nerdy stuff.

This version will be:

  • Fully native on Windows ðŸªŸ

  • Just as secure ðŸ”

  • Easy to follow ðŸ“˜

ðŸ“˜ RayFlyer Bots â€“ Secure Code-Server + Cloudflare Tunnel on Windows

âœ… What You'll End Up With:

  • A secure, browser-based VS Code (code-server) running on your Windows machine

  • Protected by Cloudflare Tunnel at https://your-subdomain.yourdomain.com

  • Accessible from anywhereâ€”but not exposed to the public internet

  • With your secret keys and files safely managed

ðŸ›  What Youâ€™ll Need:

  • A Windows 10 or 11 PC

  • A Cloudflare account

  • A registered domain (already added to Cloudflare)

  • Admin rights on your PC

ðŸš€ Step 1: Install code-server on Windows

1. Install Node.js:

  • Go to https://nodejs.org

  • Download the LTS version and install it

2. Install code-server via npm:

Open PowerShell as Administrator and run:

powershell
npm install -g code-server

3. Create a basic startup script:

In a folder like C:\code-server, create a file called start-code-server.bat with:

bat
code-server --bind-addr 127.0.0.1:8080 --auth password

The first time you run it, itâ€™ll generate a config file at:

arduino
C:\Users\<YourUsername>\AppData\Roaming\code-server\config.yaml

Edit it and make sure it looks like:

yaml
bind-addr: 127.0.0.1:8080
auth: password
password: your-secure-password-here
cert: false

Save and close.

ðŸ›° Step 2: Install Cloudflare Tunnel on Windows

1. Download cloudflared:

  • Go to: https://developers.cloudflare.com/cloudflare-one/connections/connect-apps/install-and-setup/installation

  • Download the Windows 64-bit executable

Rename it to cloudflared.exe and place it somewhere like:

makefile
C:\cloudflared\

Add that folder to your Windows system PATH (optional, but helpful).

ðŸ” Step 3: Authenticate with Cloudflare

Open a new PowerShell window and run:

powershell
cloudflared tunnel login

This will open a browser and let you log in to Cloudflare. Pick your domain.

ðŸ“¡ Step 4: Create the tunnel

powershell
cloudflared tunnel create vscode

Note the .json file it creates (we'll need that).

ðŸ“ Step 5: Create the config file

Create a new file at:

arduino
C:\Users\<YourUsername>\.cloudflared\config.yml

Put this in (adjust your path):

yaml
tunnel: vscode
credentials-file: C:\Users\<YourUsername>\.cloudflared\vscode-tunnel-credentials.json

ingress:
  - hostname: code.yourdomain.com
    service: http://localhost:8080
  - service: http_status:404

ðŸŒ Step 6: Route your subdomain

powershell
cloudflared tunnel route dns vscode code.yourdomain.com

ðŸ§­ Step 7: Run the tunnel

For now, test it manually:

powershell
cloudflared tunnel --config C:\Users\<YourUsername>\.cloudflared\config.yml run

ðŸ”„ Step 8: Auto-start Everything

Create a .bat file like this:

bat
@echo off
start "" "C:\Program Files\nodejs\code-server.cmd" --bind-addr 127.0.0.1:8080 --auth password
start "" "C:\cloudflared\cloudflared.exe" tunnel --config C:\Users\<YourUsername>\.cloudflared\config.yml run

Place it in your Startup folder:

mathematica
C:\Users\<YourUsername>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup

Now it starts automatically at login.

ðŸ›¡ Bonus: Hide .env Files in code-server

Inside VS Code:

  1. Press Ctrl+Shift+P â†’ "Preferences: Open Settings (JSON)"

  2. Add:

json
"files.exclude": {
  "**/.env": true
},
"search.exclude": {
  "**/.env": true
}

âœ… You're Done!

Now you can visit:

arduino
https://code.yourdomain.com

And log into your browser-based VS Code from anywhereâ€”with all your files safe at home.

You said:
do you think running my code server slows down my bots while im at home
ChatGPT said:

Great questionâ€”and it's smart of you to think about performance like this.

TL;DR:

No, running code-server doesnâ€™t meaningfully slow down your botsâ€”as long as your system has a decent amount of CPU and memory.

ðŸ§  Hereâ€™s whatâ€™s happening under the hood:

code-server (aka VS Code in the browser):

  • Uses some RAM and CPU for rendering the interface and background services

  • Usually runs one Node process and maybe a few helpers (10â€“15% CPU at most on lower-end machines)

Your bots:

  • Are probably running in their own Node.js processes

  • They only compete for CPU/memory if you're doing something heavy in the editor (like running a local web server or building TypeScript constantly)

ðŸ§ª Want to verify it?

You can check in real-time:

bash
htop

or in PowerShell on Windows:

powershell
Get-Process | Sort-Object CPU -Descending | Select-Object -First 10

Look at:

  • code-server (or node if running via command line)

  • Your bot processes

Youâ€™ll see pretty quick if one is spiking or starving the other.

âœ… Pro Tips:

  • If you're editing bots but not actively working, just close the tabâ€”code-server keeps running but uses fewer resources

  • If your system is low-spec (like <4GB RAM), you might notice a little slowdown

  • Want to be ultra-clean? Run bots with pm2 or tmux in their own process and restart code-server only when needed

ðŸš€ Bottom line:

Unless youâ€™re on a toaster of a computer or doing some massive compiling inside code-server, youâ€™re totally fine. Your bots won't even blink while you're logged in.

Want to try stress testing or setting up simple performance logging for peace of mind?

You said:
htop Command 'htop' not found, but can be installed with: sudo snap install htop # version 3.4.0, or sudo apt install htop # version 3.2.2-2
ChatGPT said:

Perfectâ€”that just means you donâ€™t have it installed yet, but itâ€™s easy and safe to add. You can use either method, but I recommend the apt version for simplicity.

ðŸ§° Install htop on your Linux box:

bash
sudo apt install htop

After it installs, just run:

bash
htop

ðŸ” What you'll see:

  • A colorful, real-time view of your CPU, memory, and active processes

  • Look for:

    • node (your bots)

    • code-server

    • Any other resource hogs

You can sort by CPU or memory by pressing F6 to change sort columns.

Let me know what you see or if you want help interpreting the output. It's a super handy tool to have around!

You said:
ChatGPT said:

Nice screenshotâ€”thanks for sharing that!

Hereâ€™s what Iâ€™m seeing:

ðŸ” System Overview:

  • Memory: You're using 6.5GB out of 11.5GB total â€” plenty of headroom

  • Swap: Only 2.98MB used out of 4GB â€” excellent (no memory pressure)

  • CPU: All 12 cores are mostly idle (most at 0â€“2%) â€” no CPU bottleneck

  • Load average: ~2.5 across the board = healthy for a multi-core system (12 cores = max load of 12)

ðŸ”Ž Top processes:

You're mostly seeing a bunch of Brave browser instances (/snap/brave/...) using 0% CPU and tiny bits of memory (0.6%).

I donâ€™t see your code-server or any bots in this top list, which probably means:

  • Theyâ€™re either idle (not using much CPU)

  • Or not currently running

âœ… Bottom Line:

Your system is not under any stress. Running code-server alongside your bots is no problem at all.

Youâ€™ve got:

  • Headroom on CPU

  • Plenty of RAM

  • No swap pressure

Youâ€™re golden.

Want to:

  • Keep htop running in the background occasionally?

  • Set up auto-logging of your bot CPU usage?

  • See how code-server + a busy bot affects system performance?

Just say the wordâ€”we can totally build that in.

You said:
No i just wanted to check
ChatGPT said:

Totally fairâ€”and honestly? You're running a tight ship, Captain. ðŸ›«

No performance worries at all based on that snapshotâ€”your setup is solid. Bots and code-server can cruise side-by-side all day with room to spare.

If you ever feel a slowdown or just want to geek out on fine-tuning, you know Iâ€™ve got your six. But for now? Youâ€™re smooth flying. ðŸ§‘â€âœˆï¸âš™ï¸ðŸ’»

Anything else on your mind, or are we coasting in chill mode now?

You said:
How can i check internet speed from terminal
ChatGPT said:

Niceâ€”checking internet speed from the terminal is super handy, and itâ€™s really easy too.

Here are two solid options you can use right from your Linux terminal:

ðŸš€ Option 1: Use speedtest-cli (most common)

ðŸ› ï¸ Install it:

bash
sudo apt install speedtest-cli

Then run:

bash
speedtest

Youâ€™ll see your:

  • ðŸŽï¸ Download speed

  • ðŸš€ Upload speed

  • ðŸ›°ï¸ Ping

  • ðŸ’¡ Test server location

âš¡ Option 2: Use fast (lightweight from Netflix)

This one is dead simple and fast:

Install it:

bash
sudo apt install fast

Then just run:

bash
fast

It only shows download speed, but itâ€™s super quick.

âœ… Pro Tip (Optional):

If you want a clean JSON result for logging:

bash
speedtest --json

Thatâ€™s great if you're ever scripting it or want alerts when your speed dips below a threshold.

Let me know which one you wanna roll with, or if you want help setting up a scheduled check or alert script!

You said:
it seems i have that the bots are sometimes loosing websocket connection
ChatGPT said:

Ah yeahâ€”intermittent websocket drops can be frustrating, especially when your bots rely on real-time data like trading feeds or memecoin price streams.

Letâ€™s break down the likely causes and how to troubleshoot or fix them ðŸ‘‡

ðŸ” Common Causes of WebSocket Disconnects

1. Internet Blips or ISP Buffering

Even with good overall speeds, momentary packet loss or jitter can cause WebSocket timeouts.

  • ðŸ” These might be invisible unless you're constantly connected to real-time services

  • Check for drops using:

    bash
    ping google.com

    or for more details:

    bash
    mtr google.com

2. Bot Code Doesnâ€™t Handle Reconnects Gracefully

Some bots terminate if the WebSocket closes once.

  • âœ… Make sure your bot includes auto-reconnect logic, like:

    js
    ws.on('close', () => {
  setTimeout(connectWebSocket, 5000); // reconnect after delay
});

3. Cloudflare Tunnel Idle Timeouts (less likely, but possible)

If youâ€™re proxying via Cloudflare and your bot connects to WebSocket APIs, Cloudflare could interfere if it's routing traffic through the tunnel (not common unless it's serving the WebSocket).

  • If your bot connects out to external APIs (like Binance, Coinbase, etc.), Cloudflare isn't in the way.

  • If you're serving a WebSocket via tunnel (like a dashboard), then we can tweak tunnel config to help.

4. Firewall or Router Timeout

Your local network or router might close long-lived idle connections.

  • You can try increasing keep-alive pings in your bot code.

    js
    setInterval(() => {
  if (ws.readyState === WebSocket.OPEN) {
    ws.ping(); // or send a no-op
  }
}, 30000); // every 30 seconds

5. Too Many Concurrent Connections (Rate Limits)

Exchanges and APIs often limit the number of open sockets per IP.

  • Try spreading load across time

  • Use REST APIs when real-time isnâ€™t necessary

âœ… Action Plan (Simple First)

  1. Test Internet Stability

    bash
    ping -c 50 google.com

    or

    bash
    mtr google.com

    â†’ Look for packet loss or high jitter.

  2. Check if bot logs show a disconnect reason Like "ECONNRESET", "1006: Abnormal Closure", etc.

  3. Add reconnect + keep-alive logic to your bots I can help you drop this into your current script if you want.

Want to paste part of your WebSocket bot code here? I can help you add robust reconnect handling and keep it bulletproof. ðŸ’ª

You said:

const MAX_INACTIVITY = ${WORKER_MAX_INACTIVITY}; let lastPing = Date.now(); parentPort.on('message', (msg) => { if (msg === 'ping') { lastPing = Date.now(); parentPort.postMessage('debug_ping_received'); } }); setInterval(() => { parentPort.postMessage('debug_status'); if (Date.now() - lastPing > MAX_INACTIVITY) { parentPort.postMessage('recover'); } }, WATCHDOG_INTERVAL); ; watchdog = new Worker(watchdogCode, {eval: true}); Protecting script from freezes!")); } function heartbeat() { lastActivityTime = Date.now(); if (watchdog) { watchdog.postMessage('ping'); } } let reconnectAttempts = 0; const MAX_RECONNECT_DELAY = 23369; async function recoverAndRestart() { const INITIAL_RETRY_DELAY = 4369; if (isReconnecting) { return; } isReconnecting = true; try { console.log(chalk.bgYellow.black.bold( â•”â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•— â•‘ âš ï¸ RECOVERY INITIATED âš ï¸ â•‘ â•šâ•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•)); if (activePairContract) { activePairContract.removeAllListeners(); console.log(chalk.yellow("ðŸ”„ Removed all listeners from pair contract.")); } if (heartbeatInterval) { clearInterval(heartbeatInterval); console.log(chalk.yellow("ðŸ”„ Cleared heartbeat interval.")); } if (logWalletBalanceInterval) { clearInterval(logWalletBalanceInterval); } isMonitoring = false; isBuyInProgress = false; isSellInProgress = false; const backoff = Math.min( INITIAL_RETRY_DELAY * Math.pow(1.5, reconnectAttempts), MAX_RECONNECT_DELAY ); reconnectAttempts++; console.log(chalk.yellow(ðŸ”„ Attempting to reconnect... (Attempt ${reconnectAttempts}))); console.log(chalk.yellow(â±ï¸ Waiting ${(backoff/1000).toFixed(1)} seconds before next attempt)); await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, backoff)); try { console.log(chalk.yellow("ðŸ”„ Reinitializing providers...")); if (wsProvider && wsProvider._websocket) { wsProvider._websocket.close(); } wsProvider = new ethers.WebSocketProvider(activeNetwork.wsUrl); provider = await initializeProvider(); if (!provider) { throw new Error("Provider initialization failed"); } mevBlockerProvider = new ethers.JsonRpcProvider(activeNetwork.rpcUrl); console.log(chalk.yellow("ðŸ”„ Testing provider connections...")); await Promise.all([ wsProvider.getBlockNumber(), provider.getBlockNumber(), mevBlockerProvider.getBlockNumber() ]); reconnectAttempts = 0; console.log(chalk.yellow("ðŸ”„ Restarting heartbeat system...")); setupHeartbeat(); const pairCode = await provider.getCode(pairAddress); if (pairCode === "0x") { throw new Error("Pair contract not found"); } console.log(chalk.bgGreen.white.bold( â•”â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•— â•‘ âœ… ALL SYSTEMS REINITIALIZED âœ… â•‘ â• â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•£ â•‘ ðŸš€ Restarting monitoring... â•‘ â•šâ•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•));
